thread.title: Jerry Jones defends stake in DraftKings

title: Jerry Jones defends stake in DraftKings

And its two dominant companies, DraftKings and FanDuel, are touting lucrative opening week prizes to try to draw more customers as more competitors pop up. Len Don Diego, marketing manager for content at DraftKings, a daily fantasy sports company, works at his station at the company’s offices in Boston on Sept. 9, 2015. Photo: Stephan Savoia /Associated Press Image 16 of 16 Jerry Jones defends stake in DraftKings 1 / 16 Back to Gallery His team's horrid play hasn't been the only thing Cowboys owner Jerry Jones has had to brood over lately.
Jones is a stakeholder in DraftKings, an organization that, much like his football team, has waded into treacherous waters.
Last week, DraftKings received a subpoena from U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara's office asking for information about an employee's activities and potential misuse of inside data.
The subpoena seeks information on employee Ethan Haskell, who won $350,000 playing on rival site FanDuel — the initial domino that set off a chain reaction in the daily fantasy sports (DFS) world.
Subscribe to Spurs Nation
Current
Nevada regulators have already banned DFS in their state until the companies apply for a gaming license, a double-edged sword which would effectively destroy the leverage granted to them by the Unlawful Internet Gambling Enforcement Act of 2006.
That statute acts as a ban against all forms of Internet gambling, but carves out an exception for fantasy sports that meet certain requirements.
But now, both that law and the companies it has allowed to explode onto the scene find themselves under intense scrutiny.
RELATED: Explosion of Daily Fantasy Sports draws scrutiny
None of this has caused Jones to waver.
"From my perspective, anything that follows the rules, that causes and creates more interest and more fan participation, I'm really for," Jones said following the Cowboys 27-20 loss to the Giants, per ESPN's Darren Rovell . "So I'm a supporter and that's the rules that we'll test — is put your money where your mouth is."
"I don't think DraftKings or FanDuel in any way compromise our players on the football field because it's all fantasy," Jones said. "It has no bearing on the outcome of the game at all."
NFL players are allowed to play fantasy games, but their counterparts in the NBA and MLB are prohibited from doing so.
If daily fantasy games are reclassified as gambling the NFL will be forced to bar players not only from playing, but from appearing in any of their advertisements, lest they become the modern Pete Rose.
And Jones isn't the only NFL owner defending his dubious partnership.
The Kraft Group — founded by New England Patriots owner Robert Kraft, who should be accustomed to controversy by now — also holds a stake in the fantasy gaming giant.
Kraft's son, Jonathan, defended the legality of DraftKings and DFS on a Patriots pregame show on 98.5 The Sports Hub.
"Congress made it legal," Jonathan said. "It's interesting to me, over the last month or so with all the yelling out of Washington about how this is an unregulated industry — well, they have the right to regulate it. They chose to make it legal and not pass regulations."
Regulations appear to be coming, the ripple effect of which could reverberate throughout all four major sports leagues.
It might not be long before the Cowboys and Patriots have to bid farewell to their stadium's freshly minted DraftKings-branded sports lounges.
For Jones, this would be yet another loss in a season full of them.
nmoyle@express-news.net
Twitter: @NRMoyle
